construction, Lp spaces

Find a non-empty closed set in the Hilbert space L2([0,1])L^2\p{\br{0, 1}}L2([0,1]) that does not contain an element of smallest norm.
Solution.

Let fn=nχ[0,1n2+1n3]f_n = n\chi_{\br{0, \frac{1}{n^2} + \frac{1}{n^3}}}fn​=nχ[0,n21​+n31​]​ and consider A={fn∣n≥1}⊆L2([0,1])A = \set{f_n \mid n \geq 1} \subseteq L^2\p{\br{0, 1}}A={fn​∣n≥1}⊆L2([0,1]).

First, notice that

∫[0,1]∣fn∣2=n2(1n2+1n3)=1+1n,\int_{\br{0,1}} \abs{f_n}^2 = n^2 \p{\frac{1}{n^2} + \frac{1}{n^3}} = 1 + \frac{1}{n},∫[0,1]​∣fn​∣2=n2(n21​+n31​)=1+n1​,

so AAA does not have an element with minimal normal. Furthermore, AAA is closed. Indeed, suppose there is a sequence {fnj}⊆A\set{f_{n_j}} \subseteq A{fnj​​}⊆A which converges to f∈L2([0,1])f \in L^2\p{\br{0, 1}}f∈L2([0,1]). Passing to a subsequence if necessary, we may assume that fnj(x)f_{n_j}\p{x}fnj​​(x) converges to f(x)f\p{x}f(x) almost everywhere.

If J≔{nj∣j≥1}J \coloneqq \set{n_j \mid j \geq 1}J:={nj​∣j≥1} is bounded, then f∈Af \in Af∈A, since each fnf_nfn​ is isolated. Otherwise, if JJJ is unbounded, there exists a subsequence {njk}\set{n_{j_k}}{njk​​} which increases to ∞\infty∞. Since {fnj}\set{f_{n_j}}{fnj​​} converges pointwise almost everywhere to fff, so must every subsequence, so

f(x)=lim⁡j→∞fnj(x)=lim⁡k→∞fnjk(x)=lim⁡n→∞fn(x)=0f\p{x} = \lim_{j\to\infty} f_{n_j}\p{x} = \lim_{k\to\infty} f_{n_{j_k}}\p{x} = \lim_{n\to\infty} f_n\p{x} = 0f(x)=j→∞lim​fnj​​(x)=k→∞lim​fnjk​​​(x)=n→∞lim​fn​(x)=0

almost everywhere. But this would mean that

1≤lim⁡n→∞∥fn∥L2=∥f∥L2=0,1 \leq \lim_{n\to\infty} \norm{f_n}_{L^2} = \norm{f}_{L^2} = 0,1≤n→∞lim​∥fn​∥L2​=∥f∥L2​=0,

which is impossible. Hence, JJJ must have been bounded to begin with, i.e., every convergent sequence in AAA converges in AAA, so AAA is closed.
